text.0: to him vaiśvānara who strengthens holy law to agni we present our praise like oil made pure.
text.1: with thoughtful insight human priests bring him anear our herald from of old as an axe forms a car.
text.2: he made the heaven and earth resplendent by his birth child of two mothers he was meet to be implored.
text.3: agni oblationbearer gracious everyoung infallible rich in radiant light the guest of men.
text.4: within the range of their surpassinq power by might the gods created agni with inventive thought.
text.5: i eager to win strength address him like a steed resplendent with his brilliance with his ample light.
text.6: eager to gain we crave from him the friendly god strength confident choiceworthy meet to be extolled.
text.7: the bhṛgus bounty willing strong with sages lore even agni shining forth with light that comes from heaven.
text.8: for happiness men having trimmed the sacred grass set agni glorious for his strength before them here.
text.9: yea with raised ladles him bright dear to all the gods perfecting aims of works rudra of solemn rites.
text.10: around thy dwellingplace o brightlyshining priest are men at sacrifice whose sacred grass is trimmed.
text.11: wishing to do thee service agni they are there desirous of thy friendship grant them store of wealth.
text.12: he hath filled heaven and earth and the great realm of light when at his birth the skilful held him in their hold.
text.13: he like a horse is led forth to the sacrifice sage graciously inclined that he may win us strength.
text.14: honour the oblationbearer him who knows fair rites serve ye the household friend who knows all things that be.
text.15: he drives the chariot of the lofty ordinance agni most active is the great high priest of gods.
text.16: they who are free from death fain for him purified three splendours of the mighty agni circling all.
text.17: to man for his enjoyment one of these they gave the other two have passed into the sister sphere.
text.18: mans sacrificial food hath sharpened like an axe for brightness him the sage of men the peoples lord.
text.19: busied with sacred rites he mounts and he descends he hath laid down his vital germ within these worlds.
text.20: he stirs with life in wombs dissimilar in kind born as a lion or a loudlybellowing bull.
text.21: vaiśvānara immortal with widereaching might bestowing goods and wealth on him who offiers gifts.
text.22: vaiśvānara as of old mounted the cope of heaven heavens ridge well greeted by those skilled in noble songs.
text.23: he as of old producing riches for the folk still watchful traversesthe common way again.
text.24: for new prosperity we seek to agni him whose course is splendid goldhaired excellently bright.
text.25: whom mātariśvan stablished dweller in the heaven meet for high praise and holy sage and true to law.
text.26: as pure and swift of course beholder of the light who stands in heavens bright sphere a sign who wakes at dawn.
text.27: agni the head of heaven whom none may turn asideto him the powerful with mighty prayer we seek.
text.28: the cheerful priest the pure in whom no guile is found friend of the house praiseworthy dear to all mankind.
text.29: fair to behold for beauty like a splendid caragni the friend of men we ever seek for wealth.
